clinical_study.brief_title: Uveitis in Relation to Perceived Stress: A Prospective Study
clinical_study.official_title: Uveitis in Relation to Perceived Stress: A Prospective Study

lead_sponsor.agency: The New York Eye & Ear Infirmary

clinical_study.source: The New York Eye & Ear Infirmary

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to conduct a prospective analysis to determine the relationship between disease activity of noninfectious uveitis and stress.

detailed_description.textblock: Patients presenting at The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary (NYEEI) who meet the inclusion criteria will be recruited prospectively. Patients diagnosed with non-infectious uveitis will be asked to self-administer the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS) - 10, following informed consent. Patient demographics will also be collected. The presence of inflammation will be then be assessed by the investigator. Patients will be asked to complete the PSS-10 again at all subsequent standard-of-care visits within a 6-month timeframe. PSS-10 scores are obtained by reversing the scores on the four positive items (4, 5, 7 and 8), then summing across all 10 items. Patient and the investigator will be masked to the PSS scores.

study_pop.textblock: Patients presenting at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary diagnosed with uveitis

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- At least 18 years of age with a diagnosis of non-infectious uveitis
- Able to self-administer the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS) - 10
Exclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of infectious uveitis
